-- Create test tables
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS employees (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100),
    department VARCHAR(50),
    salary DECIMAL(10,2),
    hire_date DATE
)

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS salary_history (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    employee_id INT REFERENCES employees(id),
    old_salary DECIMAL(10,2),
    new_salary DECIMAL(10,2),
    change_date TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    reason VARCHAR(200)
)

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS audit_log (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    action VARCHAR(100),
    details TEXT,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
)

-- Insert sample data
INSERT INTO employees (name, department, salary, hire_date) VALUES
    ('Alice Johnson', 'Engineering', 75000.00, '2020-01-15'),
    ('Bob Smith', 'Sales', 60000.00, '2019-06-20'),
    ('Carol White', 'Engineering', 80000.00, '2018-03-10'),
    ('David Brown', 'HR', 55000.00, '2021-08-05')
SELECT * FROM employees

-- Procedure: Give salary raise to employee
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION give_raise(
    p_employee_id INT,
    p_raise_amount DECIMAL(10,2),
    p_reason VARCHAR(200)
) RETURNS TABLE(
    status VARCHAR(20),
    employee_name VARCHAR(100),
    old_salary DECIMAL(10,2),
    new_salary DECIMAL(10,2),
    message TEXT
) AS $$
DECLARE
    v_current_salary DECIMAL(10,2);
    v_employee_name VARCHAR(100);
    v_department VARCHAR(50);
    v_new_salary DECIMAL(10,2);
    v_max_raise DECIMAL(10,2) := 20000.00; -- Max raise allowed
BEGIN
    -- Step 1: Get employee details (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 24)
    SELECT name, department, salary 
    INTO v_employee_name, v_department, v_current_salary
    FROM employees 
    WHERE id = p_employee_id;
    
    -- Step 2: Check if employee exists (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 31)
    IF NOT FOUND THEN
        RETURN QUERY SELECT 
            'ERROR'::VARCHAR, 
            NULL::VARCHAR, 
            NULL::DECIMAL, 
            NULL::DECIMAL,
            'Employee not found'::TEXT;
        RETURN;
    END IF;
    
    -- Step 3: Log the raise attempt (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 42)
    INSERT INTO audit_log (action, details)
    VALUES (
        'RAISE_ATTEMPT',
        format('Employee %s (%s) raise of $%s requested', 
               v_employee_name, p_employee_id, p_raise_amount)
    );
    
    -- Step 4: Validate raise amount (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 51)
    IF p_raise_amount <= 0 THEN
        RETURN QUERY SELECT 
            'ERROR'::VARCHAR,
            v_employee_name,
            v_current_salary,
            v_current_salary,
            'Raise amount must be positive'::TEXT;
        RETURN;
    END IF;
    
    -- Step 5: Check if raise exceeds maximum (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 62)
    IF p_raise_amount > v_max_raise THEN
        RETURN QUERY SELECT 
            'ERROR'::VARCHAR,
            v_employee_name,
            v_current_salary,
            v_current_salary,
            format('Raise exceeds maximum allowed: $%s', v_max_raise)::TEXT;
        RETURN;
    END IF;
    
    -- Step 6: Calculate new salary (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 73)
    v_new_salary := v_current_salary + p_raise_amount;
    
    -- Step 7: Record in salary history (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 76)
    INSERT INTO salary_history (employee_id, old_salary, new_salary, reason)
    VALUES (p_employee_id, v_current_salary, v_new_salary, p_reason);
    
    -- Step 8: Update employee salary (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 80)
    UPDATE employees 
    SET salary = v_new_salary 
    WHERE id = p_employee_id;
    
    -- Step 9: Log success (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 85)
    INSERT INTO audit_log (action, details)
    VALUES (
        'RAISE_SUCCESS',
        format('Employee %s salary increased from $%s to $%s', 
               v_employee_name, v_current_salary, v_new_salary)
    );
    
    -- Step 10: Return success result (SET BREAKPOINT - Line 94)
    RETURN QUERY SELECT 
        'SUCCESS'::VARCHAR,
        v_employee_name,
        v_current_salary,
        v_new_salary,
        format('Raise of $%s applied successfully', p_raise_amount)::TEXT;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql

-- Give Alice a $5,000 raise
SELECT * FROM give_raise(1, 5000.00, 'Annual performance review')

-- Verify results
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE id = 1
SELECT * FROM salary_history ORDER BY id DESC LIMIT 1
SELECT * FROM audit_log ORDER BY id DESC LIMIT 2
